nodes.bodyText: Ive not heard of this before, not sure what other people think?
GOURD is fine. We also have a GourdBlock class.
Whats the reasoning behind this? SNOW seems fine?
I agree, especially since the block is minecraft:snow.
To make it clearer between SNOW_BLOCK and SNOW
I also want to clarify this since 1.17 (iirc the right version) will have "snowier snow," so I want to clarify this as much as possible so that it doesn't become out of date soon
We don't yet know what Mojang is going to do. I'd rather change it later than change it now and later find out the change was in the wrong direction.
As it stands now, this name still clarifies the blocks that use this material.
This is used by dirt as well. I dont think this is correct
Dirt is considered topsoil as well
Dirt is not exclusively topsoil.

yes, but everything with this material can be described as topsoil. The purpose of this name is to narrow down the overgeneralized name of "earth" to make it more descriptive. "Earth" is far too broad, so if you have an alternative name I'm open to suggestions.
Not really an improvement
"Earth" is too broad of a name. "Topsoil" is closer to what the blocks are.
Shouldn't "topsoil" be two words? TOP_SOIL
Topsoil is one word.
Still don't think this is an improvement.
Changed to SOIL as per feedback
Not sure on the reasoning behind this, its only used by clay?
It's not, it's used by infested blocks, honey blocks, honeycomb blocks, and slime blocks. Clay is the odd man out
what is the property of the material?
Has the same properties as EARTH, SAND, NETHER_WOOD, and a few others, only differing in the color
just say "xxx colored earth"
CLAY can also be considered decayed organic material from animals, so it somewhat fits with this name.
SQUISHY
What about clay makes it MOB_DERIVED? What does that even mean?

Realistically, clay is made of organic material, usually from animals (mobs).
Every other block with this material is from some action or produce of a mob, ie derived from a mob.
No, the names should reflect how they are prgramatically used. This material has nothing to do with entities
Simply keep with how they are programmatically used is not in keeping with how Materials have ever been named, and to switch to such a system would only add confusion.
This one definitely doesn't work since clay isn't "MOB_DERIVED" and even for the other blocks that are, it's a very strange name. SQUISHY is pretty good, as suggested above.
Another suggestion was "moldable." Will hold off editing for more feedback.
Does it make sense to call anything "moldable" when molding isn't a thing you can do in minecraft?
Why the change here, is called Packed ice in vanilla?
It's also used for blue ice, which is another type of dense ice.
Again, not sure the resaoning behind this?
Yeah, it's only used for both types of seagrass.

And ANVIL used to only be used for anvils, and now the name is misleading. This material only differs from AQUATIC_PLANT by being replaceable, so changing this is to make it clearer to devs who want to get any of the plants that exist underwater.
This also brings it more inline with what PLANT was already doing in terms of naming
No, this is used by more than just decroation blocks?
I'm open to suggestions, but PART isn't very descriptive

Used for skulls, torches, potted plants, ladders, redstone components, and rails.
Perhaps SUBBLOCK?
like fluid loggable block? redstone components and rails are circuits

None of the blocks in this material are fluid loggable (except maybe ladders).
If SUBBLOCK is already in use for fluid logging then that won't work for a material name in this case. PART seems like a multipart or part of something else, which these are not. Initially chose DECORATION as that's what's on the wiki (per the original issue), and PART is just too vague.
This sounds a bit weird. It's used for powder-like falling blocks (sands, soul sand, gravel and concrete powder), so maybe POWDER?
or FALLABLE?
I prefer AGGREGATE over POWDER. FALLABLE is not in keeping with the rest of the materials being some descriptor of what the blocks are/are made from

Aggregate is vaguely familliar. Looking it up, I get the definition "a natural mixture of sand, gravel, and crushed stone" in the context of geology, though I agree it's a little too technical. If you use it, this will require a Javadoc.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aggregate_(geology)
Aggregate is a fairly common term. Regardless, it is more descriptive of these blocks than "sand" or "powder."
perhaps PARTICLES?
"Particles" is used elsewhere by the game, and you can't really call gravel particles. "Aggregate" is more descriptive.
The block is minecraft:bamboo_sapling. (see also #1189 (comment))

Dried kelp can be used for food, and I'm ignoring the odd man out of mycelium.
The goal is to make the name clearer as to what blocks it represents. Suggestions are welcome.
compared to clay, this one is like raw biomass/living biomass while clay/honey block etc are non-living bio-derived stuff

the fodder is that most of the blocks in it are a food source, or storage of one
I'm implying that mooshrooms eat mycelium with that name, but fodder encompasses most of the blocks in that material
since organic is far too broad

ORGANIC -> BIO or BIOMASS
I'm not sure what fodder means, other than something you throw dock for pigs to eat.
Fodder is the storage of food for later use. This or a synonym would function well. Biomass is far too general for this group.
Not an improvement because it loses accuracy for certain of the blocks with the material
FODDER -> SOLID_ORGANIC to better encompass all the blocks that use it, and to narrow down the blocks it applies to
FORGING_STATION like
This material does not include the smithing table, so FORGING_STATION seems odd
good

.>Pumpkin
.>material for -barrier- metal blocks.
Uuuh....
(The comment is for METAL)
Yes, we should start using split than unified diffs. unified diffs are confusing!
This is how it actually looks in split diff @Sollace

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		COMMENT
Is this really necessary? It's not enough that the name of the field is WATER, we have to specify that it's for water too?
Likewise applies to other jds in this PR.
Did it for consistency, and because blocks could be added to this material at any time, so would need the JD/rename at that point.
Doesn't address the issue. These comments are all redundant.
All ice can melt (irl). Rather specify on the other one that it's for ice that can't melt, or specify here which one to use for ice that cannot melt instead.
Not all ice in MC can melt. That is included in the JD because it isn't included in the name.

All ice can melt (In Real Life) is what I mean. Meltable is the default state and implied by the name "ice".
Saying that this is ice that can melt is redundant. You should rather mention where the behaviour is a divergence from the expected behaviour.
Hence, don't say this is ice that can melt, say the other one is ice that cannot melt and link to it from this one.

yes, the name ice implies that it is meltable, but it also implies that it is all ice, which it is not.
A link to the unmeltable kind can be added, but keeping what is already there in the JD will enhance clarity

Please remove this piece of useless javadocs

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for ice that can melt. {@see DENSE_ICE} for unmeltable ice.
          
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for ice that can melt. See {@link #DENSE_ICE} for unmeltable ice.
Redundant. The name already says everything you need to know.
Why does this need to change? PART was fine, and if you're going to change it at least make it SUB_BLOCK.
A more descriptive name for UNUSED_PLANT would be nice for people wanting to use it
I think javadoc would be better in this case, as something like "plant_not_used_by_vanilla" is a bit awkward.
Javadoc for it was added, if a rename is desired it can be done
Sub block seems like a bit of an odd name to me because they're still just normal blocks. I think PART is just fine personally.
"Part" to me seems like a part of something, and since MC doesn't have multiparts or anything really that is assembled from "parts" it seems odd to me.
PARTIAL_BLOCK?
How is "partial" any different from "sub"?
sub usually indicates an inclusion, so people would assume it to belong to a bigger block or a multiblock. partial doesn't have this ambiguity
CHanged to PARTIAL
grass or grass blocks?
Updated.
The nether fungi aren't wood.
Unfortunately, mojang considers them wood.
Well, they're wood-like but not "nether wood logs".
The tags call them wood, they belong to the logs category, they can be used to craft wood items such as chests and sticks - they are functionally wood.
Just "nether logs" should suffice; logs are type of wood
logs will not, as the planks and other nether wood blocks use this material.

what's wrong with this description

I don't think we need to describe the chemical composition of stone in Yarn javadocs (especially here).
Rather than mentioning chemical composition, we may consider mentioning their breaking property (i.e. blocks that general can only be harvested with pickaxes and be broken faster with pickaxes)
Mention Minecraft features of these blocks, such as explosion resistance, color, breaking information, harvest information, etc.
Really? Isn't nether stem stuff under NETHER_WOOD?

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for blocks crafted from stems (Nether logs).
          
          
            
            		COMMENT Material for blocks crafted from Nether stems and hyphae.
MOB_DERIVED is not a good name. I like SQUISHY, and ORGANIC_PRODUCT could also work (inspired by @liach's comment: #1190 (comment)).
I like SQUISHY.
Could just be ORGANIC in general
ORGANIC itself will not work, as that is too broad. If ORGANGIC_PRODUCT is what is wanted, sure.
Not sure this one is descriptive. I'd consider a slab a "partial block"
What's this material for?

well, would be more common to assume slabs share material with their full block counterparts.
This material is for things like redstone components, rails, torches, ladders, etc.
A material does not describe a block shape. It describes a subset of its properties. PARTIAL_BLOCK is not a good name because it describes its shape rather than its properties.
That is not how any material is named, except in cases of clarifying it from another similar property.
What about MOUNTED? SUPPORTED?
SUPPORTED would be fine, if we're ok ignoring flower pots and the potted plants.
That's a bug, so SUPPORTED seems good to me https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MC-127036
Not confirmed as a bug, but we'll go with it then.
Skulls tho?
i think skull needs a block to attach to as well, so SUPPORTED works very well
Since this is used for skulls, supported doesn't work. I'd go with PART or COMPONENT.
@Prospector #1190 (comment)
That was before I realized skulls were part of it, which aren't "supported." Also, support isn't a property of materials so tbh thinking about it more it really doesn't make sense.
I think the wording of the javadoc could be simplified a little here: "blocks that come from mobs"?
Done
